{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Salvador Freixedo | image = SavadorFreixedo1.JPG | image_size = 270px | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Salvador Freixedo Tabarés | birth_date = 1923 | birth_place = [[O Carballiño]], [[Province of Ourense|Ourense Province]], [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]], [[Spain]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Spanish people|Spanish]] | citizenship = {{flag|Spain}} | known_for = [[Ufology]], [[Ancient Astronauts]], [[Catholic Priest]] ([[Jesuit Order]]) | occupation = [[Ufologist]], [[Parapsychologist]], [[Author]], [[Priest]] | education = [[Salamanca]], [[Universidad Pontificia Comillas|Universidad de Comillas]], [[Alma College]], [[Mont Laurier]], University of Los Angeles, [[Fordham University]] | website = | spouse = Magdalena del Amo }}
'''Salvador Freixedo''', ([[O Carballiño]], [[Province of Ourense|Ourense Province]], [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]], 1923) is a former [[Spain|Spanish]] [[Catholic]] [[priest]] and a former member of the [[Jesuit Order]]. An [[Ufologist]] and researcher of ''paranormal subjects'', he has written a number of books on the relationship between religion and extraterrestrial beings, and has been a speaker in several international UFO congresses in [[Europe]], the [[Americas]], and [[Asia]]. He is also a contributor to a number of parascientific magazines, such as ''Mundo Desconocido'' (''Unknown World''),<ref>{{cite web | url=http://andreas.faber.cat/mundo-desconocido/|title=Mundo Desconocido|accessdate=21 January 2012}}</ref> ''Karma 7'' and ''Más allá'' (''Beyond'')<ref>[[:es:Más allá de la Ciencia|Más Allá de la Ciencia]]. In its first issue there was a very controversial article from the author about ''El informe Matrix'' (''The Matrix Report'').</ref> among others. He has also appeared in a number of TV and radio shows dedicated to these subjects.
== Biography == He was born in [[O Carballiño]] ([[Province of Ourense|Ourense Province]], [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]], Spain), in 1923,<ref name=bio_salvador_freixedo>{{cite book|last=Domingo Cuadriello|first=Jorge|title=Los Españoles En Las Letras Cubanas Durante El Siglo XX: Diccionario Bio-Bibliográfico|year=2002|publisher=Editorial Renacimiento|location=Spain|isbn=84-8472-069-1|pages=74|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iWix-UC0VL8C&pg=PA74&dq=salvador+freixedo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=QKnfUNaGC9DOqAGiuoGQCA&ved=0CFwQ6AEwCTha#v=onepage&q=salvador%20freixedo&f=false}}</ref> in the bosom of a deeply religious family (his brother was a [[Jesuit]] and his sister was a [[nun]]). When he was five his family moved to Orense, and it is there where he started his first studies, attending primary school at the''Saint Vicent Paul'' nuns and secondary school at the ''Institute Otero Pedrayo''. At the age of 16 he joins the [[Jesuits|Jesuit Order]] and is ordained [[priest]] in 1953, in [[Santander, Spain|Santander]], Spain. He was a member of the jesuit order for thirty years.<ref>{{cite book|last=Denzler|first=Brenda|title=The Lure of the Edge: Scientific Passions, Religious Beliefs, and the Pursuit of Ufos|year=2001|publisher=[[University of California Press]]|location=USA|isbn=0-520-22432-9|pages=127|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BnQU2Q65lWsC&pg=PA127&dq=salvador+freixedo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=t5vfUPrhKILkqQHRwYCoCA&ved=0CF0Q6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=salvador%20freixedo&f=false}}</ref>
He lived in a number of countries in the Americas from 1947, in his role as Jesuit, teaching ''History of the Church'' in the ''Interdiocese Seminary'' of [[Santo Domingo]], and founding the ''Movement of the Christian Working Youth'' in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]]. He was the national vice-assesor of this movement in [[La Habana]].
He studied<ref>{{cite book | last=Freixedo | first=Salvador| title=¡Defendámonos de los dioses! | publisher=Editorial Quintá | location=Madrid | year=1984 | isbn=84-398-2245-6 | pages=222}}</ref> [[humanities]] in [[Salamanca]], [[philosophy]] in [[Universidad Pontificia Comillas|Universidad de Comillas]] ([[Santander, Spain|Santander]]),<ref name="bio_salvador_freixedo"/> [[theology]] in [[Alma College]] in [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]] (California), [[Asceticism|ascetics]] in [[Mont Laurier]] (Canada), [[psychology]] in the ''University of Los Angeles'' (California) and in [[Fordham University]] of [[New York City]].
Since the 1950s, his critical position on the postures of the [[Catholic Church]] and the publication of some books led him to jail and to the expulsion from countries like [[Cuba]] and [[Venezuela]], and also to his exclusion from the Jesuit Order in 1969.<ref name="expelled1">{{cite book|last=Uría|first=Ignacio|title=Iglesia y revolución en Cuba|year=2011|publisher=Ediciones Encuentro|location=Spain|isbn=978-84-9920-088-0|pages=227–229|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N1klq7qCG4gC&pg=PA227&dq=salvador+freixedo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=D67fUMCoNJKTqwGu-4GgBA&ved=0CFIQ6AEwBjhk#v=onepage&q=salvador%20freixedo&f=false}}</ref><ref name="expelled2">{{cite book|last=Virtuoso Arrieta|first=Francisco José|title=Justicia Social en Venezuela: La Preocupación Social de la Compañía de Jesús en Venezuela, 1968-1992|year=2004|publisher=[[Universidad Catolica Andres Bello]]|location=Venezuela|isbn=980-244-380-8|pages=87|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BlowUplteEQC&pg=PA87&dq=freixedo+venezuela&hl=en&sa=X&ei=9LPfUPiiE4WzqgGL5IDwAg&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=freixedo%20venezuela&f=false}}</ref>
Since the 1970s he has dedicated himself to research in the field of [[parapsychology]], in particular the [[UFO]] phenomenon and its relation to religion and human history. He has published a number of books on the subject, and founded the ''Mexican Institute of Paranormal Studies'', of which he presided over the ''First Great International Congress''<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ridpath|first=Ian|title=Flying saucers thirty years on|journal=New Scientist|date=14 July 1977|volume=75|issue=1060|pages=79|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0ev36vp4V9UC&pg=PA79&dq=salvador+freixedo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=RqTfUKv0F9SzqQHWpIG4BQ&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q=salvador%20freixedo&f=false}}</ref> organized by the former.
== Literary works ==
===1950 to 1970=== *In 1957 while he was in [[Cuba]], he wrote his first book: ''40 Cases of Social Injustice''. Due to pressure from the [[Fulgencio Batista|Batista]] government he was transferred to Puerto Rico in 1958.<ref name="expelled1"/> *In 1968, while in [[Puerto Rico]], he wrote ''My Church Sleeps'' in which he stated the Church was narrow-minded and denounced what he saw as the poor evangelical spirit of some of its leaders and what he believed to be the irrationality of some of its dogmas, for which he was excluded from the [[Jesuit Order]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Bucchioni |first1=Eugene |title=The Puerto Rican Experience: A Sociological Sourcebook |year=1973 |publisher=Littlefield, Adams & Co.|location=USA|isbn=0-87471-162-2|pages=98 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IEJ51NRWvfUC&pg=PA98&dq=salvador+freixedo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=t5vfUPrhKILkqQHRwYCoCA&ved=0CFAQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=salvador%20freixedo&f=false|author2=Francesco Cordasco}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Badillo|first=David A.|title=Latinos and the New Immigrant Church|year=2006|publisher=The Johns Hopkins University Press|location=USA|isbn=0-8018-8388-1|pages=184|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A9W3OekHm6kC&pg=PA184&dq=salvador+freixedo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=t5vfUPrhKILkqQHRwYCoCA&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=salvador%20freixedo&f=false}}</ref> In [[Spain]] his book was banned.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jesuit suspended in Puerto Rico|url=http://archive.catholicherald.co.uk/article/22nd-august-1969/2/jesuit-suspended-in-puerto-rico|accessdate=2 January 2013|newspaper=Catholic Herald|date=22 August 1969|pages=2}}</ref> *In 1970 his book ''Love, Sex, Courtship, Marriage, Children: Five Realities in Evolution (Religious myths in human relations)'' surfaced in [[Venezuela]]. He was jailed and subsequently expelled from the country.<ref name="expelled2"/>
===Since 1970===
From the time of his falling away with the Order, he dedicated himself to the study of paranormal phenomena, considering it a window to other realities and other dimensions of existence. He has published over thirty books, many discussing a possible relationship between religion and [[extraterrestrials]], such as:
*''Extraterrestres y creencias religiosas — cuando los OVNIs aterrizan los dogmas vuelan'' (1971) (Spanish: Extraterrestrials and Religious Beliefs — When UFOs Land, Dogmas Fly) *''El diabólico inconsciente — Parapsicología y Religión'' (1973) (Spanish: The Diabolical Subconscious — Parapsychology and Religion) *''Visionarios, místicos y contactos extraterrestres (La religión en la parasicología y OVNIs)'' (1977) (Spanish: Seers, Mystics, and Extraterrestrial Contact — The religion among parapsychology and UFOs) *''Israel, pueblo contacto'' (1978) (Spanish: Israel: Contact People) *''60 casos de OVNIS'' (Spanish: 60 UFO Cases) *''¿Por qué agoniza el Cristianismo?'' (1983) (Spanish: Why is Christianity Dying?) *''Diccionario sulfúrico'' (Spanish: Sulfuric Dictionary) *''Curanderismo y Curaciones por la Fe'' (1983) (Spanish: Witch-doctors and Healings by Faith) *''¡Defendámonos de los dioses!'' (1984) (Spanish: Let Us Defend Ourselves from the Gods!) *''Las apariciones de [[El Escorial]] (Las Apariciones Marianas)'' (1985) (Spanish: The Apparitions of El Escorial — The Marian Apparitions) *''Religión, política y microcefália'' (Spanish: Religion, Politics, and Microcephaly) *''El Cristianismo: un mito más'' (1986) (Spanish: Christianity, Just Another Myth) *''Los curanderos'' (1987) (Spanish: The Witch-doctors) *''La granja humana (Ellos, los dueños invisibles de este planeta)'' (1988) (Spanish: The Human Farm; They, the invisible owners of this planet) *''La amenaza extraterrestre'' (1989) (Spanish: The Alien Threat) *''Interpelación a Jesús de Nazaret'' (1989) (Spanish: Interpellation to Jesus of Nazareth) *''Apariciones religiosas : mito o realidad? ; una explicación a fenómenos como el de Villa Alemana'' (1989) (Spanish: Religious Apparitions, Myth or Reality?; an explanation of phenomena such as the one of German Village) *''Los contactados'' (1991) (Spanish: The Contactees) *''Los hijos de la Nueva Era'' (1992) (Spanish: The Children of the New Era) *''Los OVNIS, ¿una amenaza para la humanidad?'' (1992) (Spanish: UFOs, a threat for humanity?) *''Biografía del fenómeno OVNI'' (1992) (Spanish: Biography of the UFO Phenomenon) *''¿Qué son los OVNIS?'' (1993) (Spanish: What Are UFOs?) *''Fenómeno OVNI: Evidencias'' (1993) (Spanish: UFO Phenomenon, Evidence) *''En los límites del universo'' (1994) (Spanish: Among the Limits of the Universe) *''OVNIS y dioses depredadores'' (1995) (Spanish: UFOs and Predator Gods) *''Las religiones que nos separan'' (1995) (Spanish: The Religions that Divide Us) *''Videntes, visionarios y vividores'' (1998) (Spanish: Seers, Visionaries, and Deceivers) *''Un gallego llamado Cristóbal Colón, redescubridor de América'' (2002)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cristobal-colon.com/2010/11/salvador-freixedo-tabares/|title=Presentation of the aforementioned book, in which the thesis that Columbus was Galician is defended|accessdate=7 January 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120203103559/http://www.cristobal-colon.com/2010/11/salvador-freixedo-tabares/|archivedate=3 February 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> (Spanish: A Galician Called Christopher Columbus, rediscoverer of America) *''La Expaña de Z'' (2010) (Spanish: The Xpain of Z) *''Teovnilogía: El origen del mal en el mundo'' (2012)<ref>{{cite web|last=Freixedo|first=Salvador|title=Teovnilogía: El origen del mal en el mundo|url=https://www.amazon.com/Teovnilog%C3%ADa-origen-Spanish-Edition-ebook/dp/B00821630A|publisher=Ushuaia Ediciones|language=Spanish}}</ref> (Spanish: Theoufology, the root of evil in the world)

page.title: School violence in the United States

revision.text:
{{tone|date=October 2015}}
According to the U.S. [[National Center for Education Statistics]], [[school violence]] is a serious problem.<ref name="NCES">National Center for Education Statistics. (2008). [http://nces.ed.gov/pubsearch/pubsinfo.asp?pubid=2009022] ''Indicators of school crime and safety''. Retrieved 2009-02-27.</ref><ref name="CDC">Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2008). [https://www.cdc.gov/violenceprevention/pdf/SchoolViolence_FactSheet-a.pdf] ''Understanding school violence''. Retrieved 2009-02-27.</ref> In 2007, the latest year for which comprehensive data were available, a nationwide survey,<ref>{{cite journal|name-list-format=vanc| last1 = Eaton | first1 = D.K. | last2 = Kann | first2 = L. | last3 = Kinchen | first3 = S. | last4 = Shanklin | first4 = S. | last5 = Ross | first5 = J. | last6 = Hawkins | first6 = J.| last7 =Harris | year = 2008| first7 =WA| last8 =Lowry| first8 =R| last9 =McManus| first9 =T | last10 = Chyen | first10 = D | last11 = Lim | first11 = C | last12 = Brener | first12 = N. D. | last13 = Wechsler | first13 = H | title = Youth risk behavior surveillance—United States, 2007 | url = https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/ss5704a1.htm | journal = Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report. Surveillance Summaries/CDC [MMWR Surveill Summ] | volume = 57 | issue = 4| pages = 1–131 | pmid = 18528314| display-authors = 8 | author14 = Centers for Disease Control Prevention (CDC) }}</ref> conducted biennially by the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) and involving representative samples of U.S. high school students, found that 5.9% of students carried a weapon (e.g. gun, knife, etc.) on school property during the 30 days antedating the survey. The rate was three times higher among males than among females. In the 12 months antedating the survey, 7.8% of high school students reported having been threatened or injured with a weapon on school property at least once, with the prevalence rate among males twice that as among females. In the 12 months antedating the survey, 12.4% of students had been in a physical fight on school property at least once. The rate among males was twice the rate found among females. In the 30 days antedating the survey, 5.5% of students reported that because they did not feel safe, they did not go to school on at least one day. The rates for males and females were approximately equal.
The most recent U.S. data<ref>Dinkes, R., Cataldi, E.F., Lin-Kelly, W., & Snyder, T. D. (2007). [http://www.ojp.usdoj.gov/bjs/pub/pdf/iscs07.pdf] ''Indicators of school violence and safety: 2007''. Washington, DC: National Center for Education statistics and Bureau of Justice Statistics.</ref> on violent crime in which teachers were targeted indicate that 7 percent (10 percent in urban schools) of teachers in 2003 were subject to threats of injury by students. Five percent of teachers in urban schools were physically attacked, with smaller percentages in suburban and rural schools. Other members of school staffs are also at risk for violent attack, with school bus drivers being particularly vulnerable.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1097/00043764-199701000-00009 | last1 = Peek-Asa | first1 = C. | last2 = Howard | first2 = J. | last3 = Vargas | first3 = L. | last4 = Kraus | first4 = J. F. | year = 1997 | title = Incidence of non-fatal workplace assault injuries determined from employer's reports in California | url = | journal = Journal of Occupational and Environmental Medicine | volume = 39 | issue = 1| pages = 44–50 | pmid = 9029430 }}</ref>
During 2007–08, teachers’ reports of being threatened or physically attacked by students varied according to the instructional level of their school. A greater percentage of secondary school teachers (8 percent) than elementary school teachers (7 percent) reported being threatened with injury by a student, and this pattern held for teachers in suburban schools as well as for teachers in rural schools (figure 5.2 and table 5.1).<ref>Robers, S., Kemp, J., and Truman, J. (2013). Indicators of School Crime and Safety: 2012 (NCES 2013-036/NCJ 241446). National Center for Education Statistics, U.S. Department of Education, and Bureau of Justice Statistics, Office of Justice Programs, U.S. Department of Justice. Washington, DC. [http://nces.ed.gov/pubs2013/2013036.pdf]</ref>
==Controversies==
===Lax school authorities=== In 2005, on a school bus in Montgomery County, Maryland, an 11-year-old girl was attacked by a group of several older boys who, the girl said, grabbed her breasts and feigned sex acts. Also in 2005 on a school bus in [[Colonial Heights, Virginia]], south of Richmond, three boys and two girls aged 8 to 13 held an 11-year-old girl down in the back of the bus and sexually assaulted her.<ref name = "Williamson">Williamson, E., & Aratani, L. (June 14, 2005). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/06/13/AR2005061301642.html As school bus sexual assaults rise, danger often overlooked]. ''Washington Post''. B01.</ref> In the Maryland case, the child's mother, not the school, called the police, although a school administrator did notify the girl's mother (the students were not charged with sexual assault because the police mishandled the paperwork). In the Virginia case, the girl told her mother and was taken to a police station, prompting coordinated investigations by the police and the school. The bus driver testified she saw the incident happening but never stopped the bus. The girl was dropped off at her normal bus stop.
In 2008, the [[Baltimore]] School District failed to intervene in an act of violence committed against a teacher. A student had taken a [[video]] of a peer beating her art teacher. School officials ignored the problem until the video was posted on [[MySpace]].<ref name="nuefeld">Nuefeld, S. (April 10, 2008). [http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/local/baltimore_city/bal-te.md.ci.teacher10sapr10,0,601646] School violence appalls officials]. ''Baltimore Sun''.</ref> Some cases of school violence have not been brought to the attention of the authorities because school administrators have not wanted their schools labeled unsafe under the No Child Left Behind (NCLB) Act.<ref name="Williamson"/> With or without NCLB, in the US, there has been a history of underreporting violent incidents occurring in schools.<ref name="Schon">Schonfeld, I.S. (2006). School violence. In E.K. Kelloway, J. Barling, & J.J. Hurrell, Jr. (Eds). [http://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/ED494566.pdf] ''Handbook of workplace violence'' (pp. 169–229). Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications.</ref><ref>Office of the New York State Comptroller. (2006). ''Reporting of violent and disruptive incidents by public schools'' (Rep. No. 2005-S-38). Albany: Author.</ref><ref>California Legislative Analyst Office. (2009). ''Review of school crime reporting''. Sacramento: Author.</ref>
===The media=== [[School shootings]] are rare and unusual forms of school violence, and account for less than 1% of violent crimes in public schools, with an average of 16.5 deaths per year from 2001–2008.<ref name="CDC"/> There exists an uneven number of male versus female perpetrators of school shootings, where males outnumber females.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Robertz|first1=F.J.|title=Deadly Dreams: What Motivates School Shootings?|journal=Scientific American|date=August 1, 2007|pages=54-59|url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/deadly-dreams/}}</ref> Some commentators claim that media coverage encourages school violence.<ref name="brown">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1080/09620210802492807 | last1 = Brown | first1 = J. | last2 = Munn | first2 = P. | year = 2008 | title = School violence as a social problem: Charting the rise of the problem and the emerging specialist field | url = | journal = International Studies in Sociology of Education | volume = 18 | issue = 3–4| pages = 219–230 }}</ref> On the other hand, the press would likely have been faulted if it did not cover serious threats to public safety such as the [[Virginia Tech massacre]], [[Columbine High School massacre|Columbine massacre]], and [[Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting]].<ref>Zarembo, A. (June 18, 2016). Are the media complicit in mass shootings? ''Los Angeles Times''.</ref>
==See also== *[[School violence in the United Kingdom]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Like resume|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Stephen Gilson | image = <!--(filename only)--> | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = 1950<!-- {{Birth date and age|1950|MM|DD}} --> | birth_place = [[Long Beach, California]], U.S. | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | citizenship = [[Citizenship in the United States|U.S.]] | nationality = | fields =[[Theory]], [[analysis]] | workplaces = Interdisciplinary Disability Studies at the [[University of Maine]] | alma_mater = | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | website = <!-- {{URL|www.example.com}} --> | footnotes = | spouse = }} '''Stephen Gilson''' is an American [[Theory|theorist]] and [[Policy analysis|policy analyst]] who is best known for his work in [[disability]], [[Multiculturalism|diversity]], and [[health policy]] through the lens of legitimacy theory<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ccids.umaine.edu/contact-info-directions/orono/gilson/ |title=Orono Office - Stephen Gilson |publisher=University of Main |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref><ref name="cgpublisher1">{{cite web|url=http://t05.cgpublisher.com/proposals/14/index_html |title=cgpublisher.com is being upgraded |publisher=T05.cgpublisher.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QvFGAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22Explanatory+legitimacy+theory%22&q=Depoy&pgis=1 |title=Encyclopedia of disability - Google Boeken |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QvFGAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22Explanatory+legitimacy+theory%22&q=Explanatory+legitimacy+theory&pgis=1 |title=Encyclopedia of disability - Google Boeken |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref> and disjuncture theory. Co-authored with [[Elizabeth DePoy]], Gilson developed ''Explanatory Legitimacy Theory''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=Rethinking+Disability&hl=en&lr=&btnG=Search |title=Rethinking Disability - Google Scholar |publisher=Scholar.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref> Through that lens, Gilson analyzes how [[Social group|population group]] membership is assigned, is based on [[Politics|political]] purpose, and is met with formal responses that serve both intentionally and unintentionally to perpetuate segregation, economic [[status quo]], and inter-group tension. Additionally, co-authored with DePoy, Gilson developed ''Disjuncture Theory''. This theory explains disability as an interactive “ill-fit” between bodies (broadly defined) and environments (broadly defined).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/content~content=a906422769~db=all~jumptype=rss |title=Taylor & Francis Online :: Designer diversity: moving beyond categorical branding - Journal of Comparative Social Welfare - Volume 25, Issue 1 |publisher=Informaworld.com |date=2008-12-12 |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h5c3EdbYWUkC&pg=PA267&lpg=PA267&dq=Healing+the+disjuncture:+Social+work+disability+practice&source=bl&ots=i1HbwVsoja&sig=kqUPhMYExyvqLaPh-YS1Y-7tXlQ&hl=en&ei=7etlSsm4HYaeMdbWracB&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1 |title=Comprehensive Handbook of Social Work and Social Welfare: The profession of ... - Karen Marlaine Sowers, Barbara W. White, Catherine N. Dulmus - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref>
Gilson has applied legitimacy theory and disjuncture theory to the analysis and enactment of health policy and practices related to [[Health care system|access]] and to [[Preventive medicine|illness prevention]]. Along with DePoy, Gilson has implemented his vision of socially just policy based on universal access principles through the creation of a [[web portal]] that renders existing illness prevention information accessible to individuals across diversity category boundaries.<ref name="cgpublisher1"/>
Gilson has received invitations to keynote at national and international [[Academic conference|conference]]s on disability studies and distinguished lectures at [[University of Illinois at Chicago]], [[University of Michigan|University of Michigan at Ann Arbor]], [[Smith College]], [[New York University|NYU]], [[University of North Carolina]], [[Ono Academic College]], Research Institute for Health and Medical Professions, and others.
== Biography == Gilson was born in 1950 in [[Long Beach, California]], to a family of three—an older brother, Michael, and his mother and father, Janet and Arnold Gilson. Later, in 1955, a younger sister, Nancy, would join them. He spent years as an [[artist]] before earning a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in 1973, and [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] in 1991 from the [[University of Nebraska Medical Center]].
===Recent activities=== In ''Rethinking Disability'', first published in 2004, and ''Disability as Disjuncture'', currently in press, Gilson with co-author [[Elizabeth DePoy]], takes on the essentialist nature of current diversity categories with a particular focus on disability, laying bare the value foundation and political and economic purpose of “disability category” assignment and social, professional and community response. His subsequent works, also co-authored with DePoy, include ''The Human Experience'', published in 2007, ''Evaluation Practice'' (2008), ''Studying Disability'' (2010), and selected [[essay]]s and [[Academic publishing|paper]]s. This [[scholarship]] applies legitimacy and disjuncture theories to understanding theories of human description and explanation and their purposive, political use in diverse “helping professional” worlds.
Recently, Gilson, with co-author DePoy, applies design theory and practice to the analysis of diversity categories, their membership and their maintenance. In his non-profit work, he has applied this theory to the development of inexpensive, aesthetically designed [[prototype]]s, [[Plan|strategies]], and products that enhance the ability of all people to engage in healthy behaviors. In the spring 2010, Gilson received funding to study campus architectures as symbols of campus cultural policy.{{Clarify|date=March 2012}} He has also applied design and branding to the development of [[robotics]] for non-stigmatized [[Human enhancement|augmentation of human function]].
Gilson is currently [[professor]] and co-coordinator of Interdisciplinary Disability Studies at the [[University of Maine]] and a principal of ASTOS Innovations, a non-profit corporation devoted to improving equality of access to community resources in local, national, and global environments. ASTOS Innovations designs and develops model access [[solution]]s.{{what|date=January 2018}} Gilson also holds an appointment as Senior Research Fellow.{{Clarify|date=March 2012}} Ono Academic College's<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ono.ac.il/?lang=en |title=Ono Academic College website}}</ref> Research Institute for Health and Medical Professions, [[Kiryat Ono]], [[Israel]].

[[National Institutes of Health]]. Baltimore, MD, 1995. *CSWE Commission on the Role and Status of Women “Feminist Scholarship Award for 2000.” E. P. Cramer, S. F. Gilson, and E. DePoy – “Experiences of Abuse and Service Needs of Abused Women with Disabilities”. *Allan Meyers Award for Scholarship in Disability, [[American Public Health Association]], September, 2005. *Faculty Fellowship Summer Institute in Israel, Society for Peace in the Middle East, Summer, 2008. Sponsored by [[Bar-Ilan University]], [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]], [[Ben-Gurion University of the Negev]], [[Tel Aviv University]], [[University of Haifa]], [[Technion|Technion – Israel Institute of Technology]], [[Jewish National Fund]], [[Media Watch International]], Scholars for Peace in the Middle East. *2008 [[University Center for Excellence in Developmental Disabilities]] (AUCD), Multicultural Council Award for Leadership in Diversity. *2009 University of Maine, Department of Psychology, Stanley Sue Distinguished Lecture Series, Diversity Lecture - "Now guess who is coming to the diversity dinner: Disability and beyond bodies and backgrounds". *2009 [[Society for Disability Studies]] (SDS), Senior Scholar Award.

The '''Tellurometer''' was the first successful microwave [[electronic distance measurement]] equipment. The name derives from the Latin ''tellus'', meaning Earth.
[[File:Line of sight to Plynlimon - geograph.org.uk - 963435.jpg|thumb|Typical distance measurements were between mountain tops]]
==History== The original Tellurometer, known as the Micro-Distancer MRA 1, was introduced in 1957.<ref>[http://celebrating200years.noaa.gov/distance_tools/tellurometermra1.html Tellurometer MRA 1]</ref> It was invented by [[Trevor Wadley|Dr. Trevor Lloyd Wadley]] of the Telecommunications Research Laboratory of the [[South Africa]]n [[Council for Scientific and Industrial Research]] (CSIR), also responsible for the [[Wadley Loop]] receiver, which allowed precision tuning over wide bands, a task that had previously required switching out multiple [[crystal]]s.<ref>[http://www.qsl.net/vk3jeg/b_wadley.html Wadley Loop HF receivers]</ref>
==Methodology== The Tellurometer emits an electronic wave: the remote station reradiates the incoming wave in a similar wave of more complex [[modulation]], and the resulting phase shift was a measure of the distance travelled. The results appear on a [[cathode ray tube]] with circular sweep. This instrument penetrates haze and mist in daylight or darkness and has a normal range of 30–50 km but can extend up to 70 km.<ref name=history>[http://www.fig.net/pub/fig2008/papers/hs01/hs01_03_sturman_wright_2833.pdf History of the Tellurometer]</ref>
==Application== The Tellurometer design yields high accuracy distance measurements over [[geodesy|geodetic]] distances, but it is also useful for second order survey work, especially in areas where the terrain was rough and/or the temperatures extreme.
Examples of remote locations mapped using Tellurometer surveys are [[Adams Bluff]], [[Churchill Mountains]], [[Cook Mountains]], [[Jacobsen Glacier]], [[Mount Albright]], [[Mount Predoehl]], [[Mount Summerson]], [[Queen Elizabeth Range (Antarctica)|Sherwin Peak]] and [[Vogt Peak]].
The MRB2 or Hydrodist was a marine version<ref name=history /> that was used in coastal surveys and calibrating ships using other survey navigation systems.
They were used by the [[Army of the Republic of Vietnam]] in the late 1960s.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ham (Editor)|first=Paul|title=Captain Bullen's War|year=2009|publisher=Harper Collins|location=Australia|isbn=978 0 7322 8843 3}}</ref>
==Commercial exploitation== [[Plessey]], the [[United Kingdom|British]] electronics company, formed a new subsidiary known as ''Tellurometer (Pty) Limited'' in the 1960s to manufacture the product and to develop and sell derivatives.<ref name=history/> The Company subsequently introduced numerical displays, solid state transmitters, integrated circuits and eventually [[microprocessor]]s for the product.
==See also== * [[Laser rangefinder]]

'''Tolerance tax''' (Toleranzgebührer) was a [[tax]] that was levied against [[Jews]] of [[Hungary]], then part of the [[Austrian Empire]], between 1747 and 1797.<ref name="jg">JewishGen. Hungary: Assorted Census Records, 1781-1850 [database on-line]. Provo, UT, USA: The Generations Network, Inc., 2008.</ref>
The tax was based on the German statute that a Jew was obliged to pay a certain tax to be "tolerated".<ref>Wine and thorns in Tokay Valley: Jewish life in Hungary : the history of Abaújszántó, by Zahava Szász Stessel, Fairleigh Dickinson Univ Press, 1995, p. 50-51</ref>
==Under Maria Theresa (1740–1780)==
In 1747, during the reign of Empress [[Maria Theresa]], the Jews of Hungary were taxed for the privilege of remaining in the empire, and were threatened with expulsion if they did not pay.<ref name="jg"/>
On September 1, 1749, the delegates of the Hungarian Jews, except those from [[Szatmár]] County, assembled at Pressburg and met a royal commission, which informed them that they would be expelled from the country if they did not pay this tax. The frightened Jews at once agreed to do so; and the commission then demanded a yearly tax of 50,000 [[Austro-Hungarian gulden|gulden]]. This sum being excessive, the delegates protested; and although the queen had fixed 30,000 gulden as the minimum tax, they were finally able to compromise on the payment of 20,000 gulden a year for a period of eight years. The delegates were to apportion this amount among the districts; the districts, their respective sums among the communities; and the communities, theirs among the individual members.
The queen confirmed this agreement of the commission, except the eight-year clause, changing the period to three years, which she subsequently made five. The agreement, thus ratified by the queen, was brought on November 26 before the courts, which were powerless to relieve the Jews from the payment of this ''Malkegeld'' (queen's money), as they called it.
The Jews, thus burdened by new taxes, thought the time ripe for taking steps to remove their oppressive [[Disabilities (Jewish)|disabilities]]. While still at Presburg the delegates had brought their grievances before the mixed commission that was called ''delegata in puncto tolerantialis taxae et gravaminum Judeorum commissio mixta''. These complaints pictured the distress of the Jews of that time. They were not allowed to live in [[Croatia]] and [[Slavonia]], in [[Baranya (county)|Baranya]] and [[Heves County (former)|Heves]] Counties, or in several free royal towns and localities; nor might they visit the markets there. At Stuhlweissenburg ([[Székesfehérvár]]) they had to pay a poll-tax of 1 gulden, 30 [[kreuzer]] if they entered the city during the day, if only for an hour. In many places they might not even stay overnight. They therefore begged permission to settle, or at least to visit the fairs, in Croatia and Slavonia and in those places from which they had been driven in consequence of the jealousy of the [[Greeks]] and the merchants.
The Jews also had to pay heavier bridge-and ferry-tolls than the Christians; at Nagyszombat ([[Trnava]]) they had to pay three times the ordinary sum, namely, for the driver, for the vehicle, and for the animal drawing the same; and in three villages belonging to the same district they had to pay [[Toll road|toll]], although there was no toll-gate. Jews living on the estates of the nobles had to give their wives and children as [[Security interest#Pledge|pledge]]s for [[arrears]] of taxes. In Upper Hungary they asked for the revocation of the Tolerance tax imposed by the chamber of Zips County ([[Szepes]], [[Spiš]]), on the ground that otherwise the Jews living there would have to pay two such taxes; and they asked also to be relieved from a similar tax paid to the Diet. Finally, they requested that Jewish [[artisan]]s might be allowed to follow their trades in their homes undisturbed.
The commission laid these complaints before the Queen, indicating the manner in which they could be relieved; and their suggestions were subsequently willed by the queen and made into law.
The queen relieved the Jews from the Tolerance tax in Upper Hungary only. In regard to the other complaints she ordered that the Jews should specify them in detail, and that the government should remedy them insofar as they came under its jurisdiction.
The Tolerance tax had hardly been instituted when [[Michael Hirsch]] petitioned the government to be appointed primate of the Hungarian Jews in order to be able to settle difficulties that might arise among them, and to collect the tax. The government did not recommend Hirsch, but decided that in case the Jews should refuse to pay, it might be advisable to appoint a primate to adjust the matter.
Before the end of the period of five years the delegates of the Jews again met the commission at Pressburg ([[Bratislava]]) and offered to increase the amount of their tax to 25,000 gulden a year if the queen would promise that it should remain at that sum for the next ten years. The queen had other plans, however; not only did she dismiss the renewed ''gravamina'' of the Jews, but rather imposed stiffer regulations upon them. Their tax of 20,000 gulden was increased to 30,000 gulden in 1760; to 50,000 in 1772; to 80,000 in 1778; and to 160,000 in 1813.
The method of calculating the Tolerance tax varied over time and location, according to the size of household, occupation, and income-producing assets.<ref name="jg"/>
==Under Joseph II==
In 1783, Emperor [[Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor|Joseph II]], the son of Maria Theresa, allowed Jews to settle in [[Pest, Hungary|Pest]], while enacting a tolerance tax, which the Jews had to pay to the town.<ref>[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/vjw/Budapest.html The Virtual Jewish History Tour Budapest, By Rebecca Weiner]</ref>
After 1789, the Jews paid a tolerance tax of 4 guilder per family, a [[Kosher tax|tax on kosher meat]], a marriage tax, a tax on the synagogues and cemeteries of 100 guilder per year, and a quota tax of 50 guilder per year.<ref name="jg2"/>
In 1797, after the death of Joseph II, the tolerance tax and the taxes on homes and properties were replaced by a candle tax on Jewish religious candles.<ref name="jg2">[http://www.jewishgen.org/Yizkor/rzeszow/rze047.html JewishGen, The History of the Jews of Rzeszow, Chapter 7, p. 47]</ref>
In Croatia, Slavonia, and Dalmatia, further rights were granted to Jews in 1840, but the "tolerance tax" remained in force. <ref>[http://www.porges.net/JewishHistoryOfYugoslavia.html]</ref>
==See also== *[[Taxation of the Jews in Europe]] for other types of taxes imposed on the Jews * [[Jizya]] * [[1782 Edict of Tolerance]]
